newsitem.title: UK: Engineers submit Brent Spar disposal plans to Shell.
newsitem.headline: Engineers submit Brent Spar disposal plans to Shell.

text.p: Six engineering companies selected by Royal Dutch/Shell group to produce plans for disposing of the Brent Spar oil platform are to submit bids to the Anglo-Dutch oil giant by the end of Monday, a Shell spokeswoman said.

Shell asked the contractors in January to draw up detailed proposals for a total of 11 different disposal ideas after a campaign by environmental group Greenpeace in 1995 scuppered its plans to dump the platform in the Atlantic Ocean.
"The contractors will be delivering the details of their proposals to our Aberdeen office by the end of the day," the spokeswoman said.
Norway's independent advisory body Det Norske Veritas (DNV) will evaluate the technical, safety and environmental content of proposals over the next few months.
"Shell will make its choice on the basis of the DNV report and in consultation with a wide range of bodies," the spokeswoman said.
The eleven ideas that Shell chose for development range from simple scrapping to adapting the platform for use as a fish farm or a coastal defence system.
Shell hopes to present a single firm proposal for approval by Britain's Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) by the end of the year.
"We're quite sure that by the end of the year we'll have a solution...and decommissioning can go ahead in 1998," the spokeswoman said.
It must persuade the British government that the chosen alternative is better than deep sea dumping.

The Brent Spar has been parked in a Norwegian fjord since the Greenpeace campaign, which included a consumer boycott of service stations, forced the company to back down on its original dumping plans.

Shell, which operates in the North Sea as Shell UK Exploration and Production (Shell Expro), a joint venture between Shell and Exxon, estimates it would have spent almost 20 million stg on the platform's disposal even before awarding a final contract.

Of the six bidders for the contract, Norway's Kvaerner Stolt Seaway Alliance (KSSA), Brown & Root of the United States, and a joint venture between Germany's Thyssen and Norway's Aker NC all proposed onshore disposal at yards in Britain or Norway.
KSSA and Britain's Alfred McAlpine in a joint venture with France's Doris, suggested using Brent Spar for quay extension projects.
Britain's AMEC proposed using sections of the rig in a coastal defence scheme planned for the east coast of England.
KSSA and a joint venture between Britain's John D. Wood and Norway's GMC identified potential clients interested in using the top of the platform for offshore training facilities.
KSSA also proposed converting the Spar into a floating dry dock gate and for a fish farm development.
